Mar 27

Charles Murray Event Highlights On Campus Controversies Around Free Speech

Controversial speaker Charles Murray spoke on Friday, March 24, and student activists protested outside the event.

By Ben Brachfeld and Opheli Garcia Lawler

With the eyes of turn-of-the-century baseball players watching from the wall, and a fireplace keeping everyone warm, conservative sociologist Charles Murray, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and the controversial co-author of The Bell Curve, delivered a much hyped speech at the NYU Torch Club on Friday.

The content of Murray’s speech was somewhat removed from what’s made him controversial: his assertions of biological differences in IQ between the races. His 1994 book The Bell Curve drew significant controversy for making such assertions, which were criticized for, among other things, being presented as scholarly despite not being submitted for peer review.

The event, titled “Coming Apart and the 2016 Election” and sponsored by the AEI, had Murray discussing how he believes that the rise of a so-called “new upper class,” which he characterized as people with high IQs but who live in bubbles, have failed to speak to “mainstream” America. “In many ways,” Murray said, “Hillary Clinton is the apotheosis of the person in the bubble, in terms of you’re talking about a woman who hasn’t driven a car herself for 25 years.”

He spoke of how the gulf between the new upper class and “mainstream America.” Speaking directly to the audience, Murray said “many of you have lived in a world that shuts you off from mainstream America.”

A critic of President Trump, Murray nevertheless claimed to understand why the white working class voted for the president. “We have reached a situation where, with Donald Trump, it has become increasingly obvious to a lot of mainstream Americans that the people running the country don’t understand them,” he said. “And worse, the people running the country have contempt for them.”

Murray has been in the news lately as a result of his speech at Middlebury College being disrupted by activists, who later reportedly assaulted him and Middlebury professor Allison Stanger; Stanger received a concussion. The disruption has renewed the national debate surrounding free speech on campus.

The political and media elite were also composed of members of the new upper class, according to Murray. “To a very large degree, the leadership of the Democratic Party is being drawn from the new upper class. Same with journalism,” he said, adding that journalism was once a working-class profession of people with high IQs but has become a profession where everyone is from elite colleges.

Murray believes that this new upper class is composed of “cognitive elites.” He spoke of how in eight years in the 1950s, the average Harvard freshman’s SAT verbal score increased by almost a standard deviation. “Harvard went from a place with a lot of rich kids, some of whom were smart,” Murray said, “to a place with a lot of smart kids, some of whom were rich. Same thing happened at NYU.”

Murray also stressed cultural gulfs between the new upper class and the rest of the population. “The disdain of the new upper class for Coors and Budweiser is palpable,” he said. He then joked that the new upper class won’t drink any beer not brewed by Belgian elves.

Rain was falling lightly and a cold wind was whipping down the street, as twenty or so protesters stood pressed against barricades lined on the sidewalk in front of the Torch Club. They chanted things like “Hey hey, ho ho, Charles Murray has go to!” and “How do you spell racist? NYU! How do you spell classist? NYU?”

Anytime anyone entered or exited, they yelled “Shame!”

The protesters, which were made up of NYU Against Fascism and other NYU students and faculty, were not allowed to enter the building because the speech was a ticketed event. They remained outside for the entirety of the event and afterwards, as students and guests attending were leaving.

“I was attending both the Triangle Factory Fire Memorial and the Murray protest,” says Benjamin Zinevich Rodríguez, a NYU SLAM organizer who was at the protest. “Because as a society we’re always trying to make excuses for the poor being disenfranchised from society and the fire and the Bell Curve both highlight this. They both show that profit comes before the welfare of the impoverished and non-white to the rich elite. In the era of trump we can’t tolerate the normalization of eugenics and racism in justifying the stripping of welfare and scapegoating of the exploited.”

A little before 12:30 PM, an NYU graduate student who did not provide his name began asking protesters if they had read Charles Murray’s book “The Bell Curve,” and many protesters responded that they had. There wasn’t much discussion during the first ten minutes of the interaction, but after a while one individual did try to engage in conversation with the man. However, after being unable to being able to reach any sort of common ground the graduate student left, visibly irritated.

Shortly after, a moment of silence was held by the group in “honor of the 127 women and some men who died in the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire.”

“I teach German history and the history of racial persecutions,” said Marion Kaplan, Skirball Professor of Modern Jewish History, who was at the protest against Charles Murray. “My course on the Nazi Racial State starts with eugenics, the assertion, based on junk ‘science,’ that some people are inferior to others. To put it simply, Murray peddles the insidious argument that disadvantaged people are disadvantaged because, on average, they cannot compete with white men, who are intellectually, psychologically and morally superior.”

She continued to explain that these theories had been debunked and were funded by white supremacists and that many of the supporters of Charles Murray’s works were involved in white supremacy.

“Charles Murray was on our campus because a group of students invited him,” said university spokesperson John Beckman. “NYU’s going-in presumption is that if a student group or a faculty group invite a speaker to our campus, then the event will go forward and the speaker will be able to share his or her views. Whether those views are controversial is not the key issue.”

“One thing we need to be clear on: the presence of any particular speaker at this University is not a sign of endorsement of his or her views,” clarified Beckman. “Rather, it is an indication of NYU’s commitment to the free exchange of ideas. Advocates speak on a large range of issues at NYU; their doing so does not enable them to lay claim to NYU’s agreement with their views, much less our endorsement. Beyond that, I’d reiterate that we respect the right of NYU community members to protest views with which they disagree — it is an important part of the campus discourse — but expect they will do so in a way which does not prevent a speaker from being heard.”

Beckman then included the below letter, attached with the note “I also think it might be worth it for you to take a look at the statement issued by Prof Cornel West of Harvard and Prof Robert George of Princeton.”

Thanks John.

“I believe the event went well,” said Xavier Malaussena, an organizer of the Charles Murray event. “I am pleased that the security arrangements prevented disruption and allowed it to proceed. Responses from our guests about the lecture have been positive. I’d call this a success.”

When asked about those who were protesting the event, Malaussena seemed to believe they were a bit over zealous. “I’d say it was clear to all the attendees that the monster protesters believed was speaking was not present,” explained Malaussena. “I think there are good reasons to disagree with some of Charles Murray’s work, but this smear campaign attempting to label him as a white supremacist is dishonest and ignorant.”

“I don’t believe it’s a virtue to try to enforce one’s ignorance on one’s fellow students by shutting down speakers one doesn’t like,” wrote Malaussena. “I made sure the guests were of a wide ideological variety, and they all knew they were welcome to challenge Murray on anything they wanted to. If the disruptors wouldn’t behave like children, they would have been given the chance to do the same.”

Students who attended the event, those of “a wide ideological variety,” had similar sentiments on the matter.

“When you go to events that you disagree with, there are three things that can happen,” says Juney Ha, a Junior at NYU. “One, you refine your arguments against their point. Two, you learn something new and it changes or reaffirms your opinion Three, you leave having a deeper understanding and a chance at having discourse.”

“All in all, he was a brilliant lecturer, eloquent speaker, and the main points I took away was that the American Creed was at a decline, merit is based on intelligence institutionally, and IQ isn’t everything,” says Ha, who was shocked when protesters yelled “Shame!” at her as she exited the building.

“They assumed everyone who went was an alt-right fascist,” Ha continued. “And that’s unfair. I’m going to learn and I am definitely moderate-left so I’m like on your team.”

Politics Society libertarian Louis Bartholomew attended the speech, although not as a representative of the Politics Society. While Bartholomew disagrees with the most controversial aspects of The Bell Curve regarding racial differences in IQ, he nevertheless believes that the protesters were “misinformed.”

“I think they’re focusing on the fact that he uses IQ in his analysis of looking at poverty,” Bartholomew said. “They’re arguing that he uses this analysis to further stratify society. That’s the opposite of what he’s saying.”

Bartholomew believes that NYU should continue to invite controversial speakers despite the protests of the student body and faculty. He also believes that protesting these speakers is counterproductive. “Gavin McInnes, he’s stronger now that Antifa tried to shut them down, right?” he asked. “Milo Yiannopoulos is stronger because every time he speak he tries to get shut down.”

As we exited the building with Bartholomew, protesters shouted at us. One person shouted “SHAME ON YOU FOR SUPPORTING EUGENICS!” Bartholomew was amused.

“So, by inviting someone that they disagree with, I apparently agree with everything they say,” he said. “It’s obvious that no one there is a liberal. Nobody here believes in the enlightenment, nobody believes in the ideals of the country that they’re living in. And that’s a shame, I think.”

Charles Murray’s talk comes after a string of controversial speakers at NYU this semester, including Gavin McInnes and Lucian Wintrich. And as campus advocates clash with the administration about affordability, inclusivity, divesting, and the status of the University as a sanctuary campus, many feel that while freedom of speech is being protected at NYU some of the University’s most vulnerable communities are not.
